title: Can I ask for a regrading of my SAT essay? - Quora

response.answer_text: NO. Please do not waste your money. Chances of College Board making a mistake, in SAT Essay section is remote. If you know you used recommended pencil and written the essay, you need not go for re scoring. This is what their official blogs say SAT Essay Scoring How the SAT Essay Is Scored Responses to the optional SAT Essay are scored using a carefully designed process. Two different people will read and score your essay.Each scorer awards 1–4 points for each dimension: reading, analysis, and writing.The two scores for each dimension are added.You’ll receive three scores for the SAT Essay—one for each dimension—ranging from 2–8 points.There is no composite SAT Essay score (the three scores are not added together) and there are no percentiles.We train every scorer to hold every student to the same standards, the ones shown on this page. Verifying Your Scores says The SAT scoring process includes an independent scoring of each essay by two qualified readers. If the two readers' scores differ by more than one point, a scoring director will score the essay. This automatic validation ensures the accuracy of the essay scoring process. Important: Essays Are Not Reread The verification of essay scores does not include rereading the essay or an appeal of the essay score. If you choose to have your essay score verified, the College Board will determine whether there was an error in the scanning or processing of the essay scores assigned by essay readers. In this situation, your adjusted score is automatically reported and your fee is refunded. The score verification fee will not be refunded for essays written in pen.

It is unlikely that your essay was mis-scored.  When I have had a student who scored low on the SAT essay, but who has always done well on school writing assignments, it is usually the case that the essay didn't fit the scoring rubric.  In most cases the problem is that the evidence in the essay wasn't specific enough.  I haven't read your essay, so I don't know if this applies to you.  However, it is a common problem.  Suppose the prompt was, "Do all people need to be creative?"  What you do NOT want to do is write something along the lines of "Creativity is an important trait.  Those who are creative will often, blah, blah, blah."  Actually you CAN, but then you want to follow it with very specific examples of people who were (or were not) creative and what happened as a result.  You can pull examples from your own experience, from history or even from fictional literature, but they need to be specific, and they need to support your point.  You can't just wax philosophical with generalities. That said, keep in mind that scoring well on the SAT essay and having written a good essay are not the same thing.  Standardized essay scores have to follow a strict rubric that doesn't leave room for a variety of writing styles or approaches.  If college admissions officers are worried about whether or not you can write, they can always go online and read the essay itself.  They know that the scoring system has unavoidable problems.  They are probably going to focus more on your admissions essays than on your SAT essay.
